comments.commentBody: I want a peace dept that get the same amount as the cia, Marines, Navy, Us Air force, Us Coast Guard, Money is to be spent here at home.. IN USA with no purchases from outside our country..

Don't worry overmuch.  The supersonic hydrogen ramjet engines that would be needed to power such a thing will never be useful.  They've been laboratory playthings for 30 years and can barely generate enough net power to keep themselves lit.  The idea that they will carry thousands of pounds of explosives for thousands of miles is fantasy.  This weapons program will only ever destroy a few more tens of billions of dollars.

For a non-American, I am inspired to see - based on the majority of these comments - that many Americans still retain their dignity and moral fiber despite the boringly transparent zealotry of their war-mongering politicians.

One piece of friendly advice: Your precious voices would be far more effective at the polls; over here, you are simply preaching to the choir. I encourage you to please invest your energy and time into educating and convincing the people who do not trouble themselves to read these forums - the same people who are easily mesmerized by shallow speeches and empty promises. That is, the average American.

Does anyone serious believe that our military is not experimenting with chemical warfare and other means of control? Why has the NY Times delved into the chem trails from aircraft, and not just military craft, but the secret caches on each and every commercial aircraft? Or, the experiments in Alaska at the HAARP facility? Extreme microwave energies and the chem trails generated by our government are the most nefarious and covert stuff every perpetuated on humanity...and totally ignores by Congress and by the media.
Funny, I didn't know the San Francisco Giants had a football team...

As a taxpayer I have a few questions:

1) Why do we need this if we have the B2 bomber? I thought the whole point of the B2 was to be "stealth" - isn't no detection better than rapid deployment?

2) Why rely on one enormous "smart" bomb when you can use dozens of cruise missiles launched from subs and ships? And won't this have less collateral damage?

3) Is a really really really smart big bomb, not just a big bomb, going to deter an Iran or N Korea more than now?

4) Wouldn't such a tremendously powerful "conventional" bomb, with the potential for catastrophic damage like a Hiroshima, give the President second thoughts of using it against an Iran or N Korea?

5) It seems the effectiveness of "smart" conventional weapons is that we can have US forces on the ground calling in the bombs, within a mile or two and still be out of harm's way. You lose that effectiveness and ground intelligence when your men have to be 10 miles away to avoid a massive nuclear-like strike.

5) If we're hit by another 9-11, who are we going to bomb with this bomb? Because chances are another 9-11 would come from a non-state actor. We can't just put a pin on the map and say "there!" The reason we didn't kill Bin Laden isn't because we didn't have the right kind of bomb; we just didn't know where he was.

6) Does a bigger bomb make a bigger deterrent against terrorists? It seems our best deterrent since 9/11 has been better intelligence and intelligence sharing, and boots on the ground in places like Afghanistan. I'm not sure those huge Daisy Cutter bombs in Afghanistan really made the difference, it was the guys on the ground with the Northern Alliance who called in the airstrikes that seem to have made the biggest difference.

So excuse my armchair quarterbacking, but it seems obvious that weapons manufacturers are looking for a new product to develop, some politicians are salivating at the prospect of bringing "jobs" to their districts, and Republicans are looking for anyway to say a Democratic president isn't protecting America.

Gen. Eisenhower warned us all about this.

If only the US govt. could dedicate this kind of ingenuity and financial muscle towards solving problems such as hunger, poverty and the spread of infectious disease in the Third World; or work on developing renewable energy and share the technology with countries incapable of developing it themselves. Then maybe, the need for such destructive weapons would diminish and the world might become a better place to live in.

These are the so called 'Rods from God' with the twist that rather than sitting up in orbit, they are launched from an ICBM.

This idea has been around since at least the early 80s, but not sure that it gives us a lot more than we already had.

Our problem is not killing targets, it is finding the targets that need killing (i.e. Osama bin Laden).

Kenny is one artist who gives the fans what they want and is one of the most approachable artist of this decade.  He is Blessed.  Peace & Love, God Bless-Ant.  Amarillo, Texas.

“Chloe” started with such high expectations, yet ended so disappointingly. It’s difficult to comprehend how a director of Egoyan’s stature could allow such an embarrassment to be released. There are many superlatives about the movie, including the cinematography, the music, the story line…until the disastrous conclusion.

comments.commentTitle: KUDOS TO  NYT  FOR PATRONISING MINIMAL CINEMA
comments.commentBody:
I agree with it all that it is uneven and the narrative is haphazard ,but it is the objure reality of being the reality itself .

The talented Nandita das is possibly one of the most natural actresses from sub -continent ,minus the gimmicks and glamour of the superstars ,but posesses an affectively existential ,ingenious and relaxed manner which makes her fit any role from a sophisticated college sophomore to a rural dalit ,and the movie despite it's minimalist approach ,resulting from lack of a surplus budget gets to touch your heartstrings in a manner that the hugely redundant bollywood musical sagas do not even come close to these days .

Yes it has not tried to cash in on the use of vulgar sentimentality or indulgent melodrama to induce sympathy for it's characters and also it is rather a mildly mellow tale of misery which does not want to exaggerate the milieu of truth by raising false concerns .

I think it is flawed but it has some thoughtful moments of realistic ponderous paradigm for people who are interested in content and truth rather than style or technique .

Having said that miss Mehreen has done very well with the challenging and controversial subject without stepping on too many toes or offending religious sensitivities .

You need to see this from the perspective of the characters rather than as an entertainment vehicle as it is motivated as a socio-political discourse and discussion into the behaviour of the multiple strarta of the indian society itself ,and mirrors the bourgeois and the peasant lifestyle and attitudes and perceptions very well in it's slight frame .

This was definitely  a Disney view and pretty tame. Still, the photography was terrific. As for the narration, I found myself wondering what a more dramatic subtext would have added to the film.  Great for kid. Kept them enthralled.

comments.commentTitle: This Criticism of The Cartel is Unfounded and Not Very Useful
comments.commentBody:
The reviewer may have done us all a service if she took the time to challenge any of the facts/figures/statistics of the movie. Instead she waved her hand saying only "The evidence may be verifiable (and even depressingly familiar)". Hence the review is nothing more than an assault on the producer's style, and on this count I also found the review came up short. The weeping child as well as the elated mother whose daughter was lucky enough to make the chartered school were a powerful way to make the point that kids are literally trapped in these awful public schools, and its corollary that vouchers could provide the answer (by allowing more parents to get their kids out of the nightmare).

Whatever problems the previous blogger is imagining that vouchers will bring to education, the girl and mother from the movie do not seem to me capable of imagining themselves in a worse situation. For the sake of such people how can any of us not give it a try? It is a good point that parents should get more active in their schools. But as the movie points out, electing a new board is a process where the establishment invests a lot of money exerting their influence. Its hard to imagine that parents are not trying in some of these places. School choice could provide another way for their voice to be heard. For certain The Cartel did offer a bit of sensationalism and drama, but it balanced it with a great deal of figures and statistics to make its case. Overall, it was a very useful documentary.

comments.commentTitle: Good, not great comic book/action flick
comments.commentBody:
Focusing on Hit-Girl as a prepubescent feminist symbol of empowerment misses the point entirely. This film is on the surface a satirical enterprise spoofing the comic book/action genre. Essentially the movie really is about (and happens to be one of my favorite movie themes) revenge.

Terrific villains in this one and they are what make the movie work. These are really bad guys, and you really do want to see their comeuppance. Entertaining and I highly recommend.

And thank you to the filmmakers for resisting the "Big Studio" desire to tone down the violence and language and possibly eliminate the Hit Girl character altogether. Your persistence and clarity of vision will pay off undoubtedly.
i watched this movie back when it came out.  its truly an excellent and thoughtful film.
Voodoo and Mass Grave

I can't believe that this movie recieved as much critical acclaim that it did. I'm sorry I personally feel this is one of the worst films directed by the Cohen bros. The film drags it wasn't very funny and the story was mediocre at best. After being wowed by "No Country For Old Men" which I thought was terrific I was expecting a lot more out of this. I did enjoy George Wyner's character however and shows that he is quite a funny actor eveybody rememeber Col. Sanders from "Spaceballs". "A Serious Man" to me is A Serious Dissapointment and am shocked because the Cohen Bros are better than this.

This is a masterpiece, Paul T. Anderson who has directed such gems like "Boogie Nights" and "Magnolia" goes a different route with "There Will Be Blood" and scores. This should have won the oscar for best picture, even though I loved "No Country For Old Men" I felt this was a much more powerful and important film which shows us how greed can take over oneself for the worst. Daniel Day-Lewis is the best actor of this generation and deserved to win the oscar.The haunting realism he brings to the film makes this a gritty masterpiece that gives an insight look at how corrupt the oil companies can be.Paul Dano was great in a dual role playing Pastor Eli Sunday and his twin brother Paul. 5 stars goes to Paul T. Anderson's epic film, if you haven't seen it please watch it today.
